blogs.title: Rethinking ADHD Support in Tertiary Education
blogs.description: Dr Natasha Arthars explores how tertiary education can better support students with ADHD. From executive functioning challenges to rethinking accommodations, discover strategies to build confidence, inclusion, and long-term success.
blogs.header: Rethinking ADHD Support in Tertiary Education
blogs.bodyText:
By Will Wheeler ‚Äì Neurodivergent Mates Podcast

Introduction: Why University Isn‚Äôt Always Built for Everyone

Higher education is often framed as the natural next step after high school. For many, it represents independence, growth, and career opportunities. But for students with ADHD, the transition from the structure of school to the self-directed nature of tertiary education can be overwhelming.

In a recent episode of Neurodivergent Mates, I spoke with Dr Natasha Arthars, researcher, educator, and valued member of the Neurodiversity Academy Advisory Board, about how universities can better support students with ADHD. Her story and research highlight the challenges, gaps, and opportunities for rethinking how tertiary education is designed.

Natasha‚Äôs Path to Academia

Natasha‚Äôs journey into higher education wasn‚Äôt straightforward. Today, she holds multiple vocational and university qualifications, has taught across VET and higher education, and completed a PhD in 2021. But before that success, she had two failed attempts at university.

On her third try, she found her stride and eventually discovered a passion for research. Her experiences now inform her work: focusing on adult learners, student engagement, and how technology ‚Äì including AI ‚Äì can improve educational outcomes.

Growing Up Undiagnosed

Like many neurodivergent people, Natasha wasn‚Äôt diagnosed in school. Her report cards followed a familiar pattern: high performance in primary school, followed by struggles in high school. Teachers said she could ‚Äúdo really well if only she applied herself.‚Äù

She describes herself as easily bored, full of anxious energy, and often in conflict with teachers. Maths class was a particular flashpoint ‚Äì she found it too easy, became disruptive, and was regularly kicked out.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt the class clown, but I was bored. I‚Äôd finish quickly, distract others, and get thrown out. Looking back, it all makes sense now.‚Äù ‚Äì Natasha

She also carried a strong sense of justice ‚Äì challenging teachers when she felt they weren‚Äôt treating students fairly. This tendency, common among ADHD and autistic individuals, created further conflict but also foreshadowed her later advocacy for students‚Äô voices.

Executive Functioning and Brain Development

To understand why ADHD presents unique challenges in tertiary education, Natasha explains executive functioning: the brain‚Äôs control system, located in the prefrontal cortex. It governs planning, working memory, impulse control, and cognitive flexibility.

For students with ADHD:

  • Planning is difficult due to time-blindness.
  • Working memory overloads quickly, leading to shutdown.
  • Impulse control lags behind peers.
  • Cognitive flexibility can be rigid, making it harder to adapt to change.

Research shows that the prefrontal cortex typically matures by the early twenties. But for those with ADHD, development can be delayed by 2‚Äì5 years. This means neurotypical students may manage independent study and deadlines in their early twenties, while ADHD students are still grappling with executive functioning skills.

The Challenge of Transitioning to University

High school provides structure: fixed timetables, daily routines, and teachers chasing students up on work. University, by contrast, expects self-directed learning. Students must plan study schedules, track deadlines, and navigate variable timetables.

For students with ADHD, this shift is jarring. Common struggles include:

  • Difficulty initiating assignments.
  • Trouble tracking multiple deadlines.
  • Overloaded working memory.
  • Poor impulse control when balancing study with social opportunities.

These challenges often result in procrastination, missed deadlines, and increased stress.

When Accommodations Miss the Mark

Most universities offer similar accommodations for ADHD students:

  • Extra time for assignments.
  • Additional exam time.
  • Quiet rooms or rest breaks during tests.

While helpful in theory, Natasha questions their real impact. Many students report that extensions simply shift deadlines without solving underlying issues.

One student in a recent Australian study explained:

‚ÄúIf I get a week‚Äôs extension, that just becomes my new due date. It doesn‚Äôt actually help me manage the workload.‚Äù

This creates a domino effect: assignments are pushed back into exam periods or holidays, leaving students perpetually behind. Research shows little evidence that extra time specifically benefits ADHD students compared to neurotypical peers.

Natasha argues that what students need is not just assessment accommodations but learning accommodations: structured support, templates, scaffolding, and proactive check-ins.

Learning Access: Making Classes More ADHD-Friendly

Natasha believes universities must move beyond ‚Äútime-based‚Äù accommodations to rethink learning access.

Practical changes include:

  • Recorded lectures: Allowing students to replay at their own pace, speed up content, or rewatch explanations.
  • Pre-released materials: Enabling students to preview content, prepare questions, and reduce cognitive overload in live classes.
  • Camera choice in online learning: Forcing cameras on can create unnecessary anxiety; giving students control respects neurodiverse needs.
  • Structured choice: Providing clear assignment templates, examples, and scaffolds prevents overwhelm.

Will added that recorded lectures would have helped him immensely ‚Äì by allowing him to process material beforehand, then attend class prepared with questions, and later review explanations again.

Building Confidence Through Early Support

Both Natasha and I agreed that early intervention is critical. Instead of throwing students ‚Äúinto the lion‚Äôs den,‚Äù support structures should begin at the start of university:

  • Scheduled check-ins with staff.
  • Guidance on executive functioning skills.
  • Building routines around planning, organisation, and prioritisation.

Confidence is a key outcome. As Natasha notes, once students feel capable, they need less support and begin to self-manage. Success builds momentum: mastering Word, PowerPoint, or referencing skills, for example, empowers students to keep going.

‚ÄúConfidence and self-efficacy shape identity. If students leave tertiary education believing they‚Äôre failures, it impacts their careers and lives long-term.‚Äù ‚Äì Natasha

The Flow-On Effect to the Workplace

Supporting students with ADHD isn‚Äôt just about education ‚Äì it has direct implications for the workplace. University graduates carry their study habits, confidence, and self-beliefs into employment.

If tertiary education builds confidence and executive functioning skills, graduates are better prepared for professional environments. If it undermines them, the cycle of underemployment and self-doubt continues.

Rethinking Support: From Accommodations to Inclusion

Ultimately, Natasha argues that universities need to shift from narrow accommodations to inclusive design. This means:

  • Viewing flexibility as essential, not optional.
  • Designing assessments and learning environments that work for all students.
  • Embedding executive functioning supports into study programs.

As student numbers grow and neurodiversity becomes more visible, institutions that fail to adapt will not only disadvantage students but also risk losing relevance in a competitive sector.

Conclusion: Time to Rethink the Model

Dr Natasha Arthars‚Äôs insights highlight the urgent need to rethink ADHD support in tertiary education. Extra time alone won‚Äôt close the gap. Instead, universities must focus on confidence, inclusion, and executive functioning supports that empower students to thrive.

Her message is clear:

‚ÄúEducation should be designed to support all students, not just those who fit the traditional mould.‚Äù

By rethinking accommodations, embedding inclusive practices, and listening to student voices, tertiary education can become a place where neurodivergent learners don‚Äôt just survive ‚Äì they succeed.

Where to Find Natasha

Connect with her on LinkedIn or find her academic work on Google Scholar.

blogs.title: Neurodiversity in Retail: Beyond the Shopfront
blogs.description: Explore how retail environments impact neurodivergent customers and employees. Natalie Phillips-Mason shares strategies for neuro-inclusive shopping, from quiet hours to staff education, and why retail must go beyond the shopfront.
blogs.header: Neurodiversity in Retail: Beyond the Shopfront
blogs.bodyText:
By Will Wheeler ‚Äì Neurodivergent Mates Podcast

Introduction: Shopping as More Than a Transaction

For most of us, shopping is routine: grab a trolley, weave through the aisles, pay, and leave. But for many neurodivergent individuals, retail environments can be overwhelming, exhausting, or even inaccessible. From harsh lighting to crowded spaces, the everyday act of shopping often becomes a barrier rather than a service.

On the Neurodivergent Mates podcast, I spoke with Natalie Phillips-Mason, change management consultant, parent, and advocate for neuro-inclusion in retail. Together, we explored how retail can evolve from being just about transactions to becoming truly inclusive spaces for employees and customers alike.

A Mixed-Neurotype Family Perspective

Natalie begins every introduction with an important context: she is part of a mixed-neurotype family. Among her immediate and extended relatives, some are formally diagnosed, others are discovering their neurodivergence later in life, and some may be undiagnosed but show clear traits.

This lived experience underpins her professional journey. Having worked in retail head offices and change management, Natalie understands both sides of the equation: the operational complexities of retail and the human impact of environments that aren‚Äôt designed inclusively.

Why Retail?

Retail matters because it‚Äôs everywhere. Around 10% of Australians work in retail, making it one of the largest employment sectors. Retail also touches almost every consumer, every day.

Natalie noticed a recurring theme in conversations with neurodivergent people: shopping experiences were consistently mentioned as stressful. Whether it was avoiding shopping centres, struggling with sensory overload, or finding stores too confusing to navigate, shopping wasn‚Äôt just inconvenient ‚Äì it was exclusionary.

This insight drove Natalie to commission her own research in 2023, surveying 600 Australian shoppers. The findings confirmed what stories had suggested: in-store and online shopping experiences differ dramatically, with physical environments often presenting unnecessary barriers.

Pain Points of the Retail Experience

  1. Parking and Planning Stress
    For many, stress begins before entering the store. Parking difficulty and crowded shopping centres cause frustration and trigger avoidance. Predictability is key: people want to know when stores will be less busy and easier to access.
  2. Navigation and Wayfinding
    Large shopping centres are confusing. Losing one‚Äôs car, struggling with signage, or facing unexpected store layouts are common complaints. Neurodivergent customers in particular benefit from clear maps, digital guides, and consistent layouts across locations.
  3. Sensory Overload
    Fluorescent lights, loud music, constant announcements, and overpowering smells (think perfume or soap stores) create overwhelming sensory environments. Many leave mid-shop, abandoning their trolleys, just to escape.
  4. Crowds and Clutter
    Peak shopping periods like Christmas or Black Friday are unbearable for some. Even regular days present challenges when aisles are blocked by restocking pallets. Beyond inconvenience, this creates real accessibility barriers for wheelchair users and parents with prams.

Inclusive Practices Emerging in Retail

Despite the challenges, some encouraging practices are emerging:

  • Quiet Hours: Supermarkets and electronics retailers are introducing dedicated times with dimmed lights, reduced noise, and minimal digital signage. These hours benefit not only neurodivergent customers but also others who prefer calm environments.
  • Sensory Maps: Bunnings has introduced sensory maps to help customers plan their visits. Wayfinding aids reduce anxiety and make large stores more predictable.
  • Flexible Uniforms: Some retailers, like JB Hi-Fi, allow staff to wear their own clothes rather than strict uniforms. For many neurodivergent employees, avoiding uncomfortable clothing is essential to regulate sensory input.
  • Self-Checkout & Communication Boards: Options such as self-service checkouts or picture-based communication boards empower customers to interact in ways that suit them best.
  • Queue Busting & Online Booking: Shoe brands and other retailers now offer online booking systems, reducing waiting times and creating more predictable shopping experiences.

Retail as a Workplace: Employee Inclusion

Natalie emphasises that shopping and working in retail are different experiences, but tightly connected. To be truly inclusive, retailers must also consider neurodivergent employees.

Key strategies include:

  • Flexible scheduling: Allowing breaks when needed for regulation.
  • Role alignment: Matching employees to roles that fit their strengths ‚Äì data analysis, merchandising, customer engagement, or behind-the-scenes logistics.
  • Sensory-friendly environments: Creating staff spaces that allow decompression and regulation.
  • Training leaders: Equipping managers with knowledge about neurodiversity, communication preferences, and reasonable adjustments.

Training vs. Education

Natalie makes an important distinction: training is often seen as a box-ticking exercise. In contrast, education should be ongoing, integrated into leadership, and grounded in lived experience.

Too often, employees complete mandatory training but fail to change behaviours. Accountability and reinforcement are essential. Retailers must build systems that measure outcomes, not just attendance.

‚ÄúLearning doesn‚Äôt stop. Neuro-inclusive practices require more than one-off training sessions ‚Äì they need cultural and behavioural change.‚Äù ‚Äì Natalie Phillips-Mason

Lessons from Overseas

Natalie‚Äôs travels offered examples of innovation:

  • Samsung‚Äôs experiential London store simulates real-life environments (kitchen, lounge, etc.), helping customers understand how technology fits into their homes.
  • IKEA combines inclusive practices with challenges, offering immersive spaces but creating overwhelming navigation for some.
  • European electronics retailers piloting daily quiet hours showcase how inclusion can be built into everyday operations, not just token gestures.

What Needs to Change?

Natalie suggests three priorities for retail leaders:

  • Educate ‚Äì Understand neuro-inclusion from both customer and employee perspectives.
  • Research ‚Äì Collect and act on data, not just anecdotes.
  • Engage ‚Äì Talk directly with neurodivergent employees and customers to design meaningful solutions.

Retailers must see inclusion not as an optional extra, but as a brand value that strengthens loyalty and broadens markets.

Conclusion: Retail as a Gateway to Belonging

Retail is more than shelves, tills, and shopping bags. It is where millions of people work, where families gather essentials, and where culture is reflected in daily life.

By addressing sensory environments, educating staff, and listening to lived experience, retailers can turn exclusion into belonging. For neurodivergent individuals, that shift can mean the difference between avoiding shops altogether and feeling welcomed as both customer and employee.

‚ÄúNeuro-inclusion in retail isn‚Äôt just about quiet hours ‚Äì it‚Äôs about rethinking the entire experience.‚Äù ‚Äì Natalie Phillips-Mason

blogs.title: Student First: Designing Curriculum with Purpose
blogs.description: Education researcher and teacher Grant Sciberras shares how curriculum design can empower students through choice, passion, and purpose. Discover how flexibility, student voice, and inclusive practices support engagement, especially for neurodivergent learners.
blogs.header: Student First: Designing Curriculum with Purpose
blogs.bodyText:
By Will Wheeler ‚Äì Neurodivergent Mates Podcast

Introduction: Beyond ‚ÄúOne-Size-Fits-All‚Äù

School is often presented as a one-way street: teachers deliver content, students consume it, and outcomes are measured by exams and grades. But what happens when students see no purpose in what they‚Äôre learning?

For many young people ‚Äì especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds or with neurodivergent profiles ‚Äì this lack of relevance leads to disengagement, resistance, or dropping out altogether.

On the Neurodivergent Mates podcast, I spoke with Grant Sciberras, a teacher turned PhD researcher, about his mission to redesign curriculum with students at the centre. His work explores how choice, relevance, and purpose can transform learning into something meaningful.

Teaching in Disadvantaged Communities

Grant began his career as an English and History teacher on a scholarship to work in low socio-economic (SES) public schools. From his earliest days, he noticed a mismatch between what the curriculum demanded and what students actually valued.

In these communities, students frequently challenged the purpose of lessons. They were open about not wanting to learn content that felt irrelevant.

‚ÄúWhen students question why they‚Äôre learning something ‚Äì like Shakespeare for the fifth year in a row ‚Äì they‚Äôre not being lazy. They‚Äôre recognising the curriculum doesn‚Äôt connect to their lives or goals.‚Äù ‚Äì Grant

Even working-class white Australian students, often overlooked in discussions about equity, were disengaged because the content didn‚Äôt reflect their realities.

The Problem with ‚ÄúCanon‚Äù Texts

As an English teacher, Grant often found himself using Shakespeare as an example. While he could personally appreciate Shakespeare, he recognised that Year 9 boys in Campbelltown often asked: ‚ÄúWhy am I learning this?‚Äù

In New South Wales, policy requires Shakespeare only once in Years 9 or 10. Yet schools often teach it every year because the Higher School Certificate (HSC) mandates it for advanced English. The result? A ‚Äúdomino effect‚Äù that filters down and forces every student ‚Äì regardless of goals ‚Äì to study the same content repeatedly.

‚ÄúAppreciation can‚Äôt be forced. We don‚Äôt need every student to value Shakespeare. What matters is whether they develop skills to engage critically with texts they care about.‚Äù

Relevance Matters: A Tale of Two Books

Grant also pointed to Lord of the Flies as another problematic text. Its bleak view of human nature has become a fixture in schools, yet real-life case studies show alternative narratives.

He cited the story of Fijian teenagers stranded on an island in the 1960s who worked together to survive peacefully ‚Äì the exact opposite of Golding‚Äôs tale.

These examples highlight how much of the curriculum is shaped by tradition rather than purpose. For disengaged or neurodivergent students, being forced through irrelevant material is a recipe for alienation.

Policy Constraints: Time and Outcomes

Two major system-level barriers stood out in Grant‚Äôs research:

  • Time Allocation ‚Äì Schools must dedicate fixed hours to core subjects like English, maths, and science. This rigid timetable leaves little room for passion projects, work experience, or personalised learning.
  • Outcomes-Driven Models ‚Äì Everything in the syllabus is framed around predetermined ‚Äúoutcomes.‚Äù These linear, one-size-fits-all goals leave no space for student-driven exploration.

‚ÄúWe call them outcomes, but they‚Äôre really just goals. Why not let students set their own?‚Äù

This rigidity particularly disadvantages neurodivergent students, who often thrive when learning is connected to their special interests.

Parents, Pressure, and Pathways

Another overlooked factor is parental influence. Many students default to university because parents insist, even when it doesn‚Äôt align with their passions.

Grant shared stories of students desperate to pursue trades but forced to stay until Year 12 because of stigma around vocational pathways. Ironically, trades often offer stronger employment and income opportunities than many degrees.

‚ÄúWe need to challenge the stigma. A student who wants to be a mechanic shouldn‚Äôt be treated as less valuable than one who wants to be a lawyer.‚Äù

Designing for Choice and Flexibility

So how can curriculum be redesigned to prioritise student purpose? Grant drew on differentiation, a teaching approach that offers flexibility in four key areas:

  • Product ‚Äì Allowing students to choose how they demonstrate learning (e.g., podcast, video, essay).
  • Process ‚Äì Flexibility in research methods, tools, or collaborative approaches.
  • Content ‚Äì Students selecting topics or case studies within broader themes.
  • Environment ‚Äì Structuring learning spaces and supports to suit diverse needs.

By shifting assessment focus from content knowledge to skills, teachers can support choice without increasing workload. For example, university assignments often let students choose any topic, while being marked on research quality, critical analysis, and communication.

A Lightbulb Moment: Letting Students Choose

One of Grant‚Äôs most powerful experiences came when he gave Year 9 students in Campbelltown total freedom for an end-of-year project.

The only requirements:

  • ~500 words equivalent,
  • multiple sources,
  • a bibliography,
  • and a topic they genuinely cared about.

One student, disengaged all year, asked if he could research when the band Tool would release their long-awaited new album. For the next six weeks ‚Äì typically a time when students switch off ‚Äì he was fully engaged, producing quality work with enthusiasm.

This experience showed the transformative power of connecting learning to personal passions.

Structure + Freedom: Finding the Balance

Grant emphasised that too much freedom can overwhelm students, especially neurodivergent ones. Like scrolling Netflix, endless options create paralysis.

The solution? Provide structured choice ‚Äì a balance between autonomy and guidance. For example:

  • Giving a menu of topics instead of unlimited options.
  • Providing templates and scaffolds for projects.
  • Offering work samples or exemplars to set clear expectations.

These strategies align with Universal Design for Learning (UDL), ensuring flexibility benefits all students, not just those with diagnosed learning differences.

Building Relationships: The Real Driver of Learning

Beyond curriculum design, Grant highlighted that teaching is fundamentally relational. Students learn best when they feel seen, respected, and encouraged.

‚ÄúWhen students choose not to learn, that‚Äôs still a choice. We need to understand why they‚Äôre making it, not just punish them for it.‚Äù

For disengaged students, a teacher who believes in them can make all the difference ‚Äì turning resistance into motivation.

Looking Ahead: Student Voice in Action

Grant is now on the board of the Australian Council for Student Voice, which advocates for embedding student perspectives in education policy. He believes normalising student input is key to building purposeful learning.

Whether at classroom level through anonymous surveys, or nationally through policy, student voice must become the default ‚Äì not the exception.

Conclusion: Purpose Before Policy

Grant Sciberras‚Äôs research underscores a simple but radical truth: education should serve students first.

By allowing students to set goals, pursue passions, and exercise choice within structured frameworks, schools can transform disengagement into empowerment.

For neurodivergent learners, this flexibility isn‚Äôt just helpful ‚Äì it‚Äôs essential. Relevance and purpose unlock motivation, while rigid, irrelevant curricula only push them further away.

‚ÄúSchool is for students. It‚Äôs time we designed it with them, not just for them.‚Äù ‚Äì Grant

blogs.header: Becoming an AuDHD Marketing Expert: Kerry Milne‚Äôs Journey
blogs.bodyText:
By Will Wheeler ‚Äì Neurodivergent Mates Podcast

Introduction: From Struggle to Strategy

For many neurodivergent people, the path from childhood to career is far from straightforward. School often feels like a hostile environment, filled with labels like lazy, distracted, or not applying themselves. Yet beyond those early setbacks, countless individuals go on to build remarkable careers powered by the very traits that once held them back.

On the Neurodivergent Mates podcast, I sat down with Kerry Milne, an AuDHD (Autistic + ADHD) marketing strategist and founder of Gap, to unpack her story. Kerry‚Äôs honesty about school struggles, late diagnosis, and anxiety paints a powerful picture of resilience. Today, she draws on her neurodivergent strengths to help businesses across Australia and beyond create smarter strategies and stronger connections.

School Days: ‚ÄúTrying Harder‚Äù Was Never Enough

Kerry describes school as a place of constant anxiety. Diagnosed with dyslexia at 13 but left undiagnosed for ADHD and autism until decades later, she was labelled as a ‚Äúgood student‚Äù who simply needed to try harder.

She remembers:

  • Struggling to read and retain information.
  • Crying every morning before school from overwhelming anxiety.
  • Tutors on weekends but still poor grades.
  • Feeling like she was letting everyone down.

‚ÄúEvery report card said the same thing: Kerry needs to try harder. But I was already trying as hard as I could.‚Äù ‚Äì Kerry

Like many neurodivergent girls in the 80s and 90s, her challenges went unseen. ADHD was considered a ‚Äúboy‚Äôs condition,‚Äù leaving Kerry to mask her struggles with compliance and people-pleasing.

Finding Refuge in Sport

While the classroom was suffocating, sport became Kerry‚Äôs lifeline. She excelled in netball, volleyball, basketball, and swimming. Coaching younger kids gave her confidence and leadership skills that academics never did.

On the court, she wasn‚Äôt the ‚Äúdumb kid.‚Äù She was skilled, intuitive, and respected. She could read micro body language and anticipate moves before they happened ‚Äì strengths that later translated into her marketing career.

From Lowest Scores to University

Kerry eventually scraped into university with the lowest possible entry score in her state. She was embarrassed when classmates somehow discovered her ranking, but relieved to have ‚Äúmade it through.‚Äù

Yet those years reinforced the pattern: her academic results didn‚Äôt reflect her intelligence. She often felt misunderstood and unsupported, especially by teachers who preferred students who didn‚Äôt require extra effort.

The Power of a Late Diagnosis

Kerry wasn‚Äôt diagnosed with ADHD and autism until her late 40s. For her, it was both liberating and heartbreaking.

‚ÄúIt was like finally being handed the manual for my brain after decades of trying to use the wrong one.‚Äù ‚Äì Kerry

The diagnosis reframed her past:

  • She wasn‚Äôt dumb, lazy, or careless.
  • Her struggles with tests, anxiety, and masking made sense.
  • She could finally embrace her differences as strengths, not flaws.

There was grief, too ‚Äì for the anxious child who cried daily, for wasted therapy sessions that never addressed the root cause, and for lost years spent trying to be someone else.

Coping Mechanisms: From Nightclubs to Networking

Kerry recalls using alcohol in her youth as a way to cope with overwhelming sensory environments. Nightclubs and pubs left her overstimulated, so she‚Äôd drink heavily just to feel ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù

Today, she avoids those environments altogether. She knows her limits and protects her energy. Networking events, for example, remain difficult:

  • Sensory overload ‚Äì the hum of lights, multiple conversations, the smell of carpets.
  • Masking ‚Äì playing the extrovert while feeling drained inside.
  • Boundaries ‚Äì saying no to environments that don‚Äôt work for her.

This self-awareness is one of her greatest shifts post-diagnosis.

How Neurodivergence Shapes Marketing Strategy

Kerry‚Äôs AuDHD traits have become assets in her marketing work:

  • Pattern recognition ‚Äì quickly spotting connections others miss.
  • Hyperfocus ‚Äì diving deep into data and insights.
  • Problem-solving creativity ‚Äì finding new ways to tackle challenges.
  • Empathy ‚Äì understanding the customer‚Äôs perspective with clarity.

She explains that for her, creativity isn‚Äôt about art. It‚Äôs about solving problems in ways others don‚Äôt think of.

Her ability to read people ‚Äì honed from years of masking and mirroring ‚Äì also made her a natural in sales. As a teenager, she sold shoes by truly listening to customers‚Äô needs and offering tailored solutions. That same empathy drives her strategies today.

The Cost of Masking in Corporate Life

Kerry‚Äôs career included senior roles at GE, Vodafone, and other global companies. On the surface, she thrived. But behind the mask, the cost was high:

  • Long hours spent catching up on work after overwhelming days of meetings.
  • Constant fear of being ‚Äúfound out‚Äù as not smart enough.
  • Burnout from masking and overcompensating.

Still, those years gave her invaluable skills ‚Äì from building frameworks to managing large-scale marketing campaigns. Today, she applies those lessons to help startups and scaling businesses without the unnecessary bureaucracy.

Leadership Through Lived Experience

Kerry‚Äôs experiences of anxiety and setbacks have deeply shaped her leadership style. She leads with empathy, recognising when others are struggling instead of dismissing them.

‚ÄúI can see when someone‚Äôs overwhelmed, because I‚Äôve been there. Instead of saying ‚Äòpick yourself up,‚Äô I ask: how can I help?‚Äù

She now speaks openly about ADHD paralysis, rejection sensitivity, and anxiety. Every time she does, people reach out to thank her for sharing the ‚Äúreal stuff‚Äù they thought they were alone in experiencing.

Lessons for Aspiring Neurodivergent Entrepreneurs

Kerry offers clear advice for others who feel like they don‚Äôt fit into the traditional mould:

  • You‚Äôre not broken. Struggling in school or corporate doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre incapable.
  • Find your tribe. Surround yourself with people who ‚Äúget‚Äù you.
  • Be authentic. The more you pretend to be someone else, the more you attract the wrong crowd.
  • Notice what you love. Instead of chasing titles, follow the activities that give you energy ‚Äì problem-solving, building, creating, helping.
  • Back yourself. Trust your instincts. Your ability to read people and connect dots is powerful.

Conclusion: Back Yourself

Kerry‚Äôs journey from anxious schoolgirl to AuDHD marketing expert shows the incredible potential of neurodivergent minds when given the right context.

She left school thinking she was dumb, only to discover she was deeply capable. She masked her way through corporate life, then used those lessons to build a business on her own terms.

Her parting advice is simple but profound:

‚ÄúBack yourself. Borrow someone else‚Äôs confidence if you need to until you find your own voice, but always back yourself.‚Äù

For every neurodivergent person who has felt out of place in school, corporate, or life: your path doesn‚Äôt have to look like everyone else‚Äôs. Like Kerry, you can lean into your strengths, redefine success, and carve out a space where you thrive.

blogs.header: Breaking the Mould: Succeeding Without Traditional Education
blogs.bodyText:
By Will Wheeler ‚Äì Neurodivergent Mates Podcast

Introduction: Why Breaking the Mould Matters

From the moment we step into a classroom, most of us are told there‚Äôs one tried-and-tested route to success: finish school, attend university, get a degree, and then land a respectable job. For some, that path works. But for others ‚Äì particularly those who are neurodivergent ‚Äì it feels restrictive, frustrating, and at times impossible.

The reality is that the world does not operate in straight lines, and neither do our lives. Many of us succeed not despite leaving the traditional path, but because we dared to take a different one.

In a recent episode of Neurodivergent Mates, I sat down with my good friend Gemma McLean to explore this very idea. Gemma‚Äôs story is one of resilience, humour, and determination. She walked away from high school without graduating, never went to university, and yet has built a thriving career in education technology while raising a family and embracing her ADHD diagnosis.

Her story is proof that success is not about ticking boxes but about breaking the mould.

Why Traditional Education Doesn‚Äôt Work for Everyone

Gemma knew from as early as Year 3 that school wasn‚Äôt for her. Sitting still, copying from textbooks, and rote learning were battles she couldn‚Äôt win. She wanted to be creative, ask questions, and connect with people ‚Äì but instead she was labelled the ‚Äúnaughty kid.‚Äù

Despite performing well in tests, she struggled to conform. Reading was painful, attention to detail was a nightmare, and being told what to do made her bristle. She often found herself in trouble not because she lacked ability, but because she thought differently.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt dumb. But I hated being told to jump through hoops to prove myself. School just wasn‚Äôt built for me.‚Äù ‚Äì Gemma

Walking Away: Choosing Herself Over the System

By her teenage years, the cracks had become impossible to ignore. When she was denied leadership positions for being ‚Äútoo disruptive,‚Äù Gemma made her decision. She walked away from school entirely.

For some, leaving early is painted as failure. For Gemma, it was survival. She needed to step outside the mould to find her own future. Teachers signed her out with relief, but she left knowing she was capable of much more.

Falling Into Vocational Education (By Accident)

One of the most pivotal moments of Gemma‚Äôs life happened by accident. She applied for a job selling ‚ÄúVET textbooks,‚Äù assuming VET meant veterinary. In fact, it meant Vocational Education and Training.

That mistake launched her into an unexpected career in education. Over the years, she built a reputation for connecting with people, understanding real-world challenges, and solving problems. Her career eventually took her to Amazon Web Services and, today, to Instructure, where she helps schools and universities implement Canvas LMS.

This path ‚Äì unconventional as it was ‚Äì became her success story.

ADHD: From Struggle to Strength

Like many neurodivergent professionals, Gemma didn‚Äôt understand her differences until later in life. Receiving an ADHD diagnosis reframed everything.

Instead of weaknesses, she began to see strengths:

  • Problem-solving creativity ‚Äì spotting shortcuts and seeing connections others miss.
  • Energy and enthusiasm ‚Äì her ‚Äúexcitable‚Äù personality drives progress.
  • Resilience ‚Äì setbacks motivate her to push harder.
  • Empathy and people skills ‚Äì building trust and authenticity in professional relationships.

‚ÄúWould I change my ADHD? Absolutely not. It makes me who I am. It‚Äôs frustrating sometimes, but it‚Äôs also my strength.‚Äù

Her diagnosis also helped her reduce imposter syndrome and anxiety. Medication gave her the clarity to manage challenges while doubling down on her natural gifts.

Redefining What Success Looks Like

In industries obsessed with degrees, Gemma‚Äôs journey proves that formal qualifications are not the only measure of capability.

She has sat in boardrooms with professors, executives, and policymakers. At first, she battled imposter syndrome. But over time she learned that her soft skills, life experience, and determination mattered just as much.

She even recalls a boss once telling her she was a ‚Äútrain wreck‚Äù who‚Äôd never achieve anything. Years later, she returned to his office ‚Äì this time as a supplier, selling him her product.

‚ÄúThat was my moment of proving him wrong. I wasn‚Äôt a train wreck. I was building a career and making an impact.‚Äù

Raising the Next Generation Differently

As a parent, Gemma is equally determined to raise her son with ADHD in ways that embrace his strengths. Homework is a constant battle, but she reframes tasks by explaining the skills they build, not just the instructions.

She also believes in real-world learning. Taking him to user groups and exposing him to experiences gives him more than worksheets ever could.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need him to be the smartest kid in class. I just need him to be the kindest.‚Äù

Overcoming Challenges Without a Degree

Breaking the mould comes with its hurdles:

  • Imposter syndrome ‚Äì questioning whether she belongs in academic discussions.
  • Rejection sensitivity ‚Äì overthinking personal setbacks and friendships.
  • Self-criticism ‚Äì holding herself to impossible standards.

Yet Gemma has turned these challenges into strengths. In sales, she reframes rejection as ‚Äúnot a no, just not right now.‚Äù In life, she‚Äôs learned to value determination over pedigree.

5 Lessons From Breaking the Mould

  1. Education is bigger than school. Learning happens in workplaces, communities, and life itself.
  2. Never reject yourself first. Let someone else say no ‚Äì you might be surprised how often they say yes.
  3. Authenticity attracts. Success flows when you stop pretending and show up as yourself.
  4. Failure is fuel. What schools call failure can become your greatest resilience training.
  5. Your tribe is out there. Sometimes your biggest cheerleaders are strangers who see your value.

Why This Matters for Neurodivergent Learners

Traditional education systems often fail neurodivergent students by trying to force everyone into one mould. Gemma‚Äôs journey is a reminder that learning and success come in many forms.

For neurodivergent individuals, the alternative paths ‚Äì vocational education, self-directed learning, entrepreneurship ‚Äì are often where creativity and innovation shine brightest.

Conclusion: Building Success on Your Own Terms

Gemma McLean‚Äôs story isn‚Äôt just about leaving school. It‚Äôs about refusing to let other people‚Äôs definitions of success dictate your future.

She walked away from the classroom, embraced her ADHD, found purpose in vocational education, and built a thriving career in technology and education. Along the way, she proved that intelligence, creativity, and resilience matter more than certificates.

Her advice is simple but powerful:

‚ÄúBe unapologetically yourself. Keep going. The people who don‚Äôt get you aren‚Äôt your people. The ones who clap the loudest ‚Äì often strangers ‚Äì are the ones who matter.‚Äù

For anyone who has ever felt like they don‚Äôt fit in, Gemma‚Äôs story is proof: you don‚Äôt need to fit the mould. You can break it ‚Äì and succeed because of it.
